**Edinburg** ([/ˈɛdɪnbɜːrɡ/](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [*ED-in-burg*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key")) is a city in and the [county seat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/County_seat "County seat") of [Hidalgo County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hidalgo_County,_Texas "Hidalgo County, Texas"), [Texas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas "Texas"), United States.[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-GR6-6) The population was 100,243 at the [2020 census](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_census "2020 United States census"),[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-2020_Census_(City)-3) and in 2022, its estimated population was 104,294,[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-USCensusEst2022-4) making it the second-largest city in Hidalgo County, and the third-largest city in the larger [Rio Grande Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rio_Grande_Valley_(Texas) "Rio Grande Valley (Texas)") region.

Edinburg is part of the [McAllen–Edinburg–Mission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McAllen%E2%80%93Edinburg%E2%80%93Mission_metropolitan_area "McAllen–Edinburg–Mission metropolitan area") and [Reynosa–McAllen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reynosa%E2%80%93McAllen_Metropolitan_Area "Reynosa–McAllen Metropolitan Area") metropolitan areas. Edinburg is home to the main campus of [University of Texas Rio Grande Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Texas_Rio_Grande_Valley "University of Texas Rio Grande Valley").

History
-------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: History")]

In 1908, John Closner, William Briggs, Argyle McAllen, Plutarco de la Viña, and Dennis B. Chapin began to develop a new community at this site. The town square was located at the current crossroads of [U.S. Highway 281](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Route_281_in_Texas "U.S. Route 281 in Texas") and [State Highway 107](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas_State_Highway_107 "Texas State Highway 107"). The town was named "Chapin" in honor of one of the developers. A local myth relates that Edinburg became the county seat of Hidalgo County in a dramatic, nighttime covert operation in which the county records were removed from the previous county seat. However, historical records show more practical reasons. The 1886 Hidalgo County Courthouse in the city of [Hidalgo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hidalgo,_Texas "Hidalgo, Texas") was under frequent danger of flooding because it stood just a few yards away from the banks of the [Rio Grande](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rio_Grande "Rio Grande"). Additionally, the county was over 80 miles (130 km) long at this time, and state law required that the courthouse be close to the geographic center of a county.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-7) A wood-frame courthouse was designed and built beside the Chapin courthouse square in 1908; construction on a grand courthouse within the square began in 1910 under the supervision of San Antonio builders and a partnership of San Antonio architects.[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-8) When Dennis Chapin was involved in the shooting death of Oscar J. Rountree at the Dan Breen Saloon in [San Antonio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Antonio "San Antonio"),[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-9) the community changed its name to "Edinburg" to honor John Young, a prominent businessman who was born in [Edinburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburgh "Edinburgh"), [Scotland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scotland "Scotland"). The town was officially renamed in 1911 and incorporated in 1919. As they grew in the 1920's in popularity the city of Edinburg was called "Gateway to the Valley" by many to attract tourists.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-10)

In 2013, the city council voted to annex about 2,000 acres (810 ha) of area into the city limits.[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-11)

Geography
---------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Geography")]

Edinburg is located in south-central Hidalgo County at 

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/WMA_button2b.png/20px-WMA_button2b.png "Show location on an interactive map") WikiMiniAtlas

[26°18′15″N 98°9′50″W﻿ / ﻿26.30417°N 98.16389°W﻿ / 26.30417; -98.16389](https://geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Edinburg,_Texas&params=26_18_15_N_98_9_50_W_type:city) (26.304225, –98.163751).[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-GR1-12) It is bordered to the south by [Pharr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pharr,_Texas "Pharr, Texas") and to the southwest by [McAllen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McAllen,_Texas "McAllen, Texas"), the largest city in the county. [U.S. Route 281](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Route_281 "U.S. Route 281") ([Interstate 69C](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstate_69C "Interstate 69C")) runs through the east side of Edinburg. US 281 leads north 103 miles (166 km) to [Alice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alice,_Texas "Alice, Texas") and 229 miles (369 km) to San Antonio. Downtown McAllen is 10 miles (16 km) to the south and west.

According to the [United States Census Bureau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau "United States Census Bureau"), Edinburg has a total area of 37.7 square miles (97.6 km2), of which 0.1 square miles (0.2 km2), or 0.16%, is covered by water.

### Climate

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Climate")]

Edinburg has a [hot semi-arid climate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hot_semi-arid_climate "Hot semi-arid climate") ([Köppen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification") *BSh*), bordering a [humid subtropical climate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate "Humid subtropical climate") (*Cfa*), characterised by hot to sweltering summers and warm winters, typical of South Texas. The all-time record high is 108 °F (42 °C) on June 22, 2023 and on May 10, 2024. Conversely, the all-time record low is 20 °F (-7 °C) on February 16, 2021 during the [February 2021 North American cold wave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/February_2021_North_American_cold_wave "February 2021 North American cold wave"). The average date of first frost is December 11, while the average date of last frost is January 25.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-13) Edinburg falls into the USDA [Plant Hardiness Zone 10a](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hardiness_zone#United_States_hardiness_zones_(USDA_scale) "Hardiness zone").[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-14)

As of the [census of 2020](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_census "2020 United States census"), there were 100,243 people, 29,899 households, and 21,635 families were residing in the city.

### 2010 census

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: 2010 census")]

As of the [census of 2010](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_United_States_census "2010 United States census"), there were 77,100 people in the city.

### 2000 census

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: 2000 census")]

As of the [census of 2000](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000_United_States_census "2000 United States census"), there were 48,465 people, 14,183 households, and 11,417 families in the city. The population density was 1,296.9 inhabitants per square mile (500.7/km2). The 16,031 housing units had an average density of 429.0 per square mile (165.6/km2). The [racial makeup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_(United_States_Census) "Race (United States Census)") of the city was 73.32% White, 0.58% African American, 0.47% Native American, 0.65% Asian, 22.71% from other races, and 2.27% from two or more races. Hispanics or Latinos of any race were 88.68% of the population. About 95% of those who selected the "other race" were Hispanic or Latino.[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-20)

Of the 14,183 households, 46.9% had children under 18 living with them, 56.9% were married couples living together, 19.0% had a female householder with no husband present, and 19.5% were not families. About 15.4% of all households were made up of individuals, and 5.5% had someone living alone who was 65 or older. The average household size was 3.29, and the average family size was 3.71.

In the city, the ag distribution was 33.0% under 18, 13.1% from 18 to 24, 29.8% from 25 to 44, 15.9% from 45 to 64, and 8.2% who were 65 or older. The median age was 27 years. For every 100 females, there were 95.3 males. For every 100 females 18 and over, there were 90.5 males.

The median income for a household in the city was $28,938, and for a family was $30,634. Males had a median income of $27,505 versus $21,010 for females. The [per capita income](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Per_capita_income "Per capita income") for the city was $11,854. About 25.2% of families and 29.2% of the population were below the [poverty line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poverty_line "Poverty line"), including 37.2% of those under 18 and 23.0% of those 65 or over.

Economy
-------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Economy")]

Several state agencies have offices in Edinburg. This includes the Thirteenth Court of Appeals, the Texas Attorney General's Child Support Unit, the Texas Departments of Health Services, Human Services, Protective and Regulatory Services, and Public Safety. The Texas Youth Commission has a facility near Edinburg. The [Texas Department of Criminal Justice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas_Department_of_Criminal_Justice "Texas Department of Criminal Justice") operates two facilities, the Lopez Unit and the Segovia Unit, in Edinburg.[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-21)[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-22)

Arts and culture
----------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Arts and culture")]

### Public libraries

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Public libraries")]

The City of Edinburg operates the Dustin Michael Sekula Memorial Library.[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-23)

### Museums

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Museums")]

Edinburg is home to the [Museum of South Texas History](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_South_Texas_History "Museum of South Texas History"), formerly the Hidalgo County Historical Museum.

### Tourism

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Tourism")]

The [Edinburg Scenic Wetlands](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg_Scenic_Wetlands&action=edit&redlink=1 "Edinburg Scenic Wetlands (page does not exist)") comprise one of nine sites of the [World Birding Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Birding_Center "World Birding Center"), a native habitat site and wildlife refuge.[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-24)

Sports
------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Sports")]

This city was the home of the [Edinburg Roadrunners](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg_Roadrunners "Edinburg Roadrunners"), an [independent league baseball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_league_baseball "Independent league baseball") team in the [North American League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_American_League_(baseball) "North American League (baseball)"), but after numerous ownership changes, the team disbanded. Currently, [UTRGV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UTRGV "UTRGV") is the only major baseball team in Edinburg.

In 2013, the city of Edinburg and the Edinburg Economic Development Corporation announced plans for the construction of an events arena in which the [NBA Development League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_Development_League "NBA Development League") champions, the [Rio Grande Valley Vipers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rio_Grande_Valley_Vipers "Rio Grande Valley Vipers"), would be the anchor tenants.[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-25) It opened in 2018. The team also has its practice facility at the Edinburg Sports and Wellness Center.[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-26) The city also opened a six-city-block stretch of green pedestrian walkway space known as the McIntyre Street Project in April 2014; it is expected to be the beginning of a proposed arts and restaurant district extending through the heart of Edinburg.[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-27)

Since 2016, the city has been home to the [Rio Grande Valley FC Toros](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rio_Grande_Valley_FC_Toros "Rio Grande Valley FC Toros") soccer club in the [USL Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USL_Championship "USL Championship"), who play at [H-E-B Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-E-B_Park "H-E-B Park").[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-houstondynamo.com-28) The city is also home to the Rio Grande Valley FC Toros Academy, a youth soccer club in the area and a pioneer in youth development for the Rio Grande Valley. The Toros Academy plays in the MLS Next league against the best academies in the nation and provides fully funded programs for U-15, U-17, and U-19 boys.

In 2025, the city of Edinburg got to host the new [2025 UT Rio Grande Valley Vaqueros football team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_UT_Rio_Grande_Valley_Vaqueros_football_team "2025 UT Rio Grande Valley Vaqueros football team") in the [Robert and Janet Vackar Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_and_Janet_Vackar_Stadium "Robert and Janet Vackar Stadium") and played on the [Southland Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southland_Conference "Southland Conference") (SLC) in the [2025 NCAA Division I FCS football season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_NCAA_Division_I_FCS_football_season "2025 NCAA Division I FCS football season"). Finishing the season 5-3 in their first conference year and 9-3 overall.

### Stadiums and arenas

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Stadiums and arenas")]

[Bert Ogden Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bert_Ogden_Arena "Bert Ogden Arena") was originally opened in August 2018, is the home for the Rio Grande Valley Vipers of the NBA G League. The capacity for basketball games is 7,688 and 9,000 for concerts. The construction cost was $88 million.

[UTRGV Baseball Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UTRGV_Baseball_Stadium "UTRGV Baseball Stadium"), commonly known as Edinburg Stadium, had its groundbreaking take place in 2000., and it opened in 2001. The stadium's capacity is 4,000 people. It was the home for the [Edinburg Roadrunners](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg_Roadrunners "Edinburg Roadrunners") (2001 to 2013). The Edinburg Roadrunners were a member of the [United League Baseball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_League_Baseball "United League Baseball") 2006 to 2010 and the [North American League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_American_League_(baseball) "North American League (baseball)") from 2011 to 2012. The land was owned by the City of Edinburg in years prior to 2014, was donated to the [University of Texas System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Texas_System "University of Texas System").

[Robert and Janet Vackar Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_and_Janet_Vackar_Stadium "Robert and Janet Vackar Stadium") is a 9,700-seat [soccer-specific stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soccer-specific_stadium "Soccer-specific stadium") home for the rio Grande Valley FC Toros of the USL Championship. The construction of the stadium was completed in 2016 and officially opened on March 22, 2017.[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-houstondynamo.com-28)

Government
----------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Government")]

As Edinburg is the county seat of Hidalgo County, most major county offices are located there, including the Criminal District Attorney's Office, the District Courts and County Courts at Law of Hidalgo County, the Community Supervision and Corrections Department, the Hidalgo County Juvenile Probation Department, the [Hidalgo County Sheriff's Office](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hidalgo_County_Sheriff%27s_Office_(Texas) "Hidalgo County Sheriff's Office (Texas)"), and the offices of the County Judge, the Tax Assessor/Collector, the County Treasurer, County Auditor and Veterans Services. Hidalgo County Commissioner's Precinct Four represents Edinburg on the Hidalgo County Commissioner's Court.

### Edinburg City Council

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Edinburg City Council")]

* [Mayor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor "Mayor") - Ramiro Garza Jr.
* Council Member Place 1 – Dan Diaz
* Council Member Place 2 – Jason De Leon
* Council Member Place 3 – David Salazar Jr.
* Council Member Place 4 – Gerardo "Gerry" Lozano

Edinburg City Council meetings are held on the first and third Tuesdays of every month starting at 6 pm in the Edinburg City Hall, Council Chambers. Anyone can attend the meetings and voice any concerns.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-29)

### Federal representation

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Federal representation")]

The [United States Border Patrol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Border_Patrol "United States Border Patrol") Rio Grande Valley Sector Headquarters is at 4400 South Expressway 281, Edinburg, Texas.

The [United States Postal Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Postal_Service "United States Postal Service") operates a postal office at 410 S Jackson Road, Edinburg, Texas.

Education
---------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Education")]

### Tertiary education

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Tertiary education")]

In December 2012, officials announced the merger of the existing [University of Texas-Pan American](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Texas-Pan_American "University of Texas-Pan American") in Edinburg and the [University of Texas at Brownsville](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Texas_at_Brownsville "University of Texas at Brownsville") into a regional institution.[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-30) A year later, in December 2013, [University of Texas System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Texas_System "University of Texas System") officials decided to name the new institution the [University of Texas Rio Grande Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Texas_Rio_Grande_Valley "University of Texas Rio Grande Valley").[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-31)[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-32) UTRGV's creation garnered much media attention because of its expected economic, social, and health-care impact on the region. UTRGV is unique in that it is the first time the UT System has merged existing campuses in such a way. UTRGV was to also bring the first medical school to the Rio Grande Valley region.[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-33) The first class of UTRGV students began courses in fall 2015.[[34]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-34)

Edinburg is also the home of the [Rio Grande Bible Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rio_Grande_Bible_Institute "Rio Grande Bible Institute").

All of Hidalgo County is in the [South Texas College](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Texas_College "South Texas College") District.[[35]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-35)

### Primary and secondary education

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Primary and secondary education")]

Almost all of the city is served by the [Edinburg Consolidated Independent School District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg_Consolidated_Independent_School_District "Edinburg Consolidated Independent School District"),[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-HidalgoCountySDMap2020-36) comprising five high schools, one alternative secondary school, six middle schools, and 20 elementary schools. [Edinburg High School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg_High_School_(Texas) "Edinburg High School (Texas)"), [Edinburg Collegiate High School](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg_Collegiate_High_School&action=edit&redlink=1 "Edinburg Collegiate High School (page does not exist)"), [Edinburg North High School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg_North_High_School "Edinburg North High School"), and [Robert Vela High School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Vela_High_School "Robert Vela High School") are in the city limits. [Johnny G. Economedes High School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economedes_High_School "Economedes High School") has an Edinburg postal address.

A small portion is served by the [McAllen Independent School District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McAllen_Independent_School_District "McAllen Independent School District"),[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-HidalgoCountySDMap2020-36) including Memorial High School, Cathey Middle School, and McAllen's Gonzalez Elementary.

In addition, the [South Texas Independent School District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Texas_Independent_School_District "South Texas Independent School District") operates magnet schools that serve Edinburg. [South Texas Business Education & Technology Academy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Texas_Business_Education_%26_Technology_Academy "South Texas Business Education & Technology Academy") is in Edinburg. Students from Edinburg also have the chance to attend other South Texas ISD schools in Mercedes: South Texas High School for the Medical Professions and the Science Academy of South Texas.

The [Roman Catholic Diocese of Brownsville](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Diocese_of_Brownsville "Roman Catholic Diocese of Brownsville") operates St. Joseph Catholic School, an elementary and middle school.

Infrastructure
--------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Infrastructure")]

### Transportation

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Transportation")]

McIntyre Street Project plans also include a bus transportation hub for [Valley Metro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valley_Metro_(Texas) "Valley Metro (Texas)"),[[69]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-69) the regional transit service.[[70]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-70)

[Greyhound](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greyhound_Lines "Greyhound Lines") provides bus service to Edinburg.[[71]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-71)

#### Highways

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Highways")]

* [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Texas_107.svg/40px-Texas_107.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Texas_107.svg) [State Highway 107](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_Highway_107_(Texas) "State Highway 107 (Texas)")
* [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Texas_336.svg/40px-Texas_336.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Texas_336.svg) [State Highway 336](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_Highway_336_(Texas) "State Highway 336 (Texas)")

* [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/I-69C.svg/40px-I-69C.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:I-69C.svg) [Interstate 69C](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstate_69C "Interstate 69C")

#### Airports

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Airports")]

Two major commercial airports are near Edinburg: [McAllen Miller International Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McAllen_Miller_International_Airport "McAllen Miller International Airport") (**MFE**) at McAllen, 20 minutes from Edinburg and [Valley International Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valley_International_Airport "Valley International Airport"), (**HRL**) in [Harlingen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harlingen,_Texas "Harlingen, Texas"), 40 minutes from Edinburg. The [South Texas International Airport at Edinburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Texas_International_Airport_at_Edinburg "South Texas International Airport at Edinburg") (**KEBG**) is a public-use airport owned and operated by the City of Edinburg.

Notable people
--------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edinburg,_Texas&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Notable people")]

* [Terry Canales](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terry_Canales "Terry Canales"), Democratic member of the [Texas House of Representatives](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas_House_of_Representatives "Texas House of Representatives") representing District 41, serving since 2013
* [Alfredo Cantu Gonzalez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfredo_Cantu_Gonzalez "Alfredo Cantu Gonzalez"), a [U.S. Marine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps "United States Marine Corps") who posthumously received the [Medal of Honor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medal_of_Honor "Medal of Honor") for service in the [Battle of Huế](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Hu%E1%BA%BF "Battle of Huế") during the [Vietnam War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnam_War "Vietnam War")
* [Monica de la Cruz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monica_De_La_Cruz "Monica De La Cruz"), Republican member of the [U.S. House of Representatives](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States House of Representatives") representing [Texas's 15th congressional district](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas%27s_15th_congressional_district "Texas's 15th congressional district"), serving since 2023[[72]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburg,_Texas#cite_note-72)
* [Robert Guerra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Guerra_(politician) "Robert Guerra (politician)"), attorney and Democratic member of the Texas House of Representatives representing District 41
* [Joe M. Kilgore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_M._Kilgore "Joe M. Kilgore"), former lawyer in Edinburg and former member of the [United States House of Representatives](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States House of Representatives") from Texas
* [Stanley A. Mulaik](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanley_A._Mulaik "Stanley A. Mulaik"), Professor Emeritus (retired) at the School of Psychology at the Georgia Institute of Technology, as well as the head of the Societate American pro Interlingua
* [Bobby Pulido](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bobby_Pulido "Bobby Pulido"), [Tejano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tejano "Tejano") singer
* [Eloy Rodriguez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eloy_Rodriguez "Eloy Rodriguez"), American scientist
* [Leslie H. Southwick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leslie_H._Southwick "Leslie H. Southwick"), [federal judge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_judge "Federal judge") on the [United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Court_of_Appeals_for_the_Fifth_Circuit "United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit") and a former judge of the [Mississippi Court of Appeals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mississippi_Court_of_Appeals "Mississippi Court of Appeals")
* [Pedro Villarreal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedro_Villarreal "Pedro Villarreal"), [Major League Baseball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_League_Baseball "Major League Baseball") pitcher
* [Grupo Frontera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grupo_Frontera "Grupo Frontera"), a Latin pop / [norteño](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norte%C3%B1o_(music) "Norteño (music)") band
